conclusion: An induced current exists only when the magnetic flux through the square loop is changing.
Flux changes while any part of the loop is crossing a field boundary; when the loop is completely outside or completely inside the uniform field, the flux is constant and no current is induced.
The front edge of the loop reaches the left boundary at t = 0.
The loop becomes fully immersed when the rear edge has just crossed that boundary.
Distance the loop must move during this stage = its own side length l.
Time for this motion = l / v.
The front edge arrives at the right-hand boundary after travelling the field width d; at that instant the loop is still fully inside, so no current.
From that instant until the rear edge leaves the field the loop covers again a distance l.
Time for this stage = l / v.
Total time interval during which the flux is changing (and a current is induced) Î”t = (l / v) + (l / v) = 2l / v.
The induced current flows for a total time t = 2l / v.
